Message.Title: DRAM $2.2 and HAUP $1.0 Two Super-undervalued Super-Low floater stocks returning to profitability are starting to move up.!!!!
Message.Msg: DRAM, with this week's 6/1 reverse split DRAM has less than a million shares in the float. The company has been around since 1967 and has survived all the economic downturns. Now that memory prices are staging a come back and thanks to recent software partnerships (with AMD and others) it can turn super-profitable. The stock is trading 20 times lower than in 2007 and it's far more diversified. Value investors should pay close attention to this one before it flies past double digits. HAUP or Hauppauge, has recently announced the launch of several HD DVRs for the gaming and other industries. These high margin products will make this low floater explode to double-digit territory. A profitable (2nd in a row) quarter will be announced soon. Take a look at DRAM's and HAUP's chart and do your DD fast because these two gems are just starting to take off and they are still under the radar.

Message.Title: CCUR has Most Momentum in the Market
Message.Msg: Concurrent (CCUR) very low float undiscovered gem, up 7 straight trading days and looks ready to explode today past $8 resistance and onto new 52-week highs above $8.45. CCUR only has 9.2mm o/s with $24.6mm in cash no debt and an enterprise value at $7.98 of $48.8mm or 0.78x revenue vs its #1 competitor Seachange (SEAC) trading with an enterprise value of 1.9x revenue, which would value CCUR at $15.60. CCUR recently announced that Virgin Media the largest cable TV company in the UK will be using CCUR's MediaHawk multi-screen video delivery technology to power their new Virgin TV Anywhere platform that allows Virgin subscribers to watch TV and on demand content from any location on their tablets or smartphones. CCUR's net income has been multiplying on a quarter-to-quarter basis. Research its fundamentals immediately and take a look at its amazing chart! CCUR has been up for 12 straight months, but its biggest gains could be set to occur over the next couple of weeks! Soon, CCUR will revolutionize the cable TV industry with the launch of their new patented cloud based DVR technology that will make traditional DVR boxes obsolete!

Message.Title: One reason why I don't like BAC
Message.Msg: Too much share dilution! Berkshire still has Bank of America warrants that could turn out to be even more profitable than the Goldman payout. As part of its $5 billion loan to BofA in 2011, Berkshire got the right to buy 700 million shares for $7.14 each. BofA is currently trading around $12, giving Berkshire a "paper profit" of $3.5 billion if the warrants were exercised now.

Topic.Title: buy BAC for the next 2 years

Message.Msg: Basic, sensible advice. Forumers are disappointed this week seeing the stock sink back down into the 12s. But it won't be trading at book value right away. It takes time for a big corporation to do things, the buyback will take place gradually over the year. They'll probably buy the preferreds first because it has an immediate effect on cash flow which the Fed will like. They have to please the Fed, before the common stock holders. Give it another 2 or 3 years, and accumulate on dips. When the earnings are viable and repeatable, the stock price will reflect that.

Message.Title: Brian Moynihan and Charlie Rose on Bloomberg
Message.Msg: The CEO looked very upbeat and positive about the future of BAC. I actually felt him beaming over the prospects of the company, however, when asked if the company could get back to $50 he stated that because of the dilution of the company in which 4 to 5 billion shares were added a price of $50 would give BAC a ridiculous market cap of 550 billion, hence the buy back now of shares and the continuation in the future. Broadening its organic operations globally and diminishing litigation against the company will eventually give BAC the constant revenue stream its been missing. The buy back of shares over increasing the dividend was the only way to go.

Topic.Title: Brian Moynihan and Charlie Rose on Bloomberg

Message.Msg: A "fair" criticism of BAC would be that it is operating in a mature market (N.A.) that is growing slowly, and it's already got a footprint in the major markets of the country. They can streamline operations, reduce overhead, and improve cash flow. But to make major change in stock price will involve expansion (probably internationally) and buying back shares. All of this takes time to do, and they still have a large chunk of Countrywide's portfolio to transfer out of their servicing book. It'll happen, but it's going to be time frame of a few years to finish "cleaning out the attic and basement of junk"

Message.Title: US BANKS WILL DO WELL TOMORROW (Thursday)
Message.Msg: Run on the bank will only happen in Cyprus, if it happens at all. This is only a Cyprus problem. All other European and the American banks will not be affected. If it did, run on the bank in Europe and here would have already happened week ago. No banks in Europe or the Americas were closed. They and we already had a plenty of time to do so. My thoughts. Good luck to you all.
